title: 108_hr2047
content: The Act may be cited as the "Encouraging Work Act of 2003" and includes modifications to the Work Opportunity Credit and Welfare-to-Work Credit. The "Encouraging Work Act of 2003" makes the Work Opportunity Credit permanent, removes termination clauses, adjusts eligibility for ex-felons regardless of family income, increases the maximum age for food stamp recipients to 40, and raises the age limit for designated community residents. The "Encouraging Work Act of 2003" makes changes to the definition of designated community residents, specifying age and residency requirements within empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or renewal communities. The "Encouraging Work Act of 2003" amends the definition of designated community residents to include age and residency requirements within empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or renewal communities. It also clarifies the treatment of individuals under individual work plans developed by employment networks. The amendments made by the "Encouraging Work Act of 2003" to the Social Security Act apply to individuals who start working for the employer after December 31, 2003. Consolidation of work opportunity credit with welfare-to-work credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new category for long-term family assistance recipients. This term is defined as individuals certified by a local agency as part of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new category for long-term family assistance recipients. These individuals must have received assistance under a IV-A program for at least 18 months before the hiring date, either as a family member receiving assistance for 18 months after August 5, 1997, or as a family member no longer eligible for assistance due to federal or state law limitations. The hiring date must be within 2 years of the end of the 18-month assistance period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes a provision for long-term family assistance recipients who have received assistance for at least 18 months before being hired. The new amendment allows for a 50% credit on qualified second-year wages for these recipients. The maximum credit for qualified second-year wages for long-term family assistance recipients is $10,000 per year. This applies to wages paid during the 1-year period after the recipient's initial 1-year period. Special rules apply for agricultural and railway labor employees. The amendments made by this section increase the maximum credit for qualified second-year wages for long-term family assistance recipients to $10,000 per year and repeal the separate Welfare-to-Work Credit. These changes apply to individuals who begin work for the employer after December 31, 2003.
